Programming Session 4

20 September 2016

I‚Äôm trying to approach coding like building a habit. Doing a bit every day will eventually help it all stick in my head. Typhoon days like today really bring that motivation down, but I‚Äôm still going at it! üôÇ

The Tic Tac Toe exercise was a bit difficult. Cole Steele‚Äôs hints set up the basic table, but it took some Googling to discover how to get rid of the table border, put borders only on certain sides, and center the whole table. I‚Äôm pretty sure there are better ways of going about this exercise, but as a newbie using just a tad bit more than what my instructor taught me, here‚Äôs what I did:

HTML

<body>
	<h1>Tic Tac Toe</h1>
	<table>
		<tr>
			<td></td>
			<td></td>
			<td></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td></td>
			<td></td>
			<td></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td></td>
			<td></td>
			<td></td>
		</tr>
	</table>
</body>

CSS

/*TITLE*/
h1 {
	text-align: center;
}

/*REMOVE BORDER, CENTER TABLE*/
table {
	border-collapse: collapse;
	margin-right: auto;
	margin-left: auto;
}

/*BOX SIZE*/
td {
	width: 100px;
	height: 100px;
}

/*LEFT OF MIDDLE SQUARE*/
tr:nth-of-type(2) td:nth-of-type(1) {
	border-top: 2px solid black;
	border-bottom: 2px solid black;
}

/*RIGHT OF MIDDLE SQUARE*/
tr:nth-of-type(2) td:nth-of-type(3) {
	border-top: 2px solid black;
	border-bottom: 2px solid black;
}

/*MIDDLE SQUARE*/
tr:nth-of-type(2) td:nth-of-type(2) {
	border: 2px solid black;
}

/*ABOVE MIDDLE SQUARE*/
tr:nth-of-type(1) td:nth-of-type(2) {
	border-left: 2px solid black;
	border-right: 2px solid black;
}

/*BELOW MIDDLE SQUARE*/
tr:nth-of-type(3) td:nth-of-type(2) {
	border-left: 2px solid black;
	border-right: 2px solid black;
}

Looking at the solutions video taught me that CSS classes were made to reduce redundant code. In short, be a lazy programmer! The less you have to type to get a result, the better! Or maybe not, but that‚Äôs what I got out of this. Incredibly similar to writing an English essay‚Ä¶

Before moving onto the next exercise, I attempted to replace all the images with some of my favorite fan art so I could take a screenshot and show off to my friends. To my surprise, I came across a conundrum: When you have images (or anything, really) of differing sizes, you can‚Äôt put them all in the same line using floats. At least, it‚Äôs not possible with pure CSS. Hopefully later on, I‚Äôll stumble across a way to solve this issue!

The ‚Äúmake a blog from scratch‚Äù exercise was really fun! I went into it a bit nervous, but Cole Steele taught well enough for me to pull off the general look without needing to look at the solution! I even found a nifty, easy way to get my <hr> to look incredibly cool. The best part about this trick is that it‚Äôs a background color, which means it‚Äôs applicable on other elements as well. I tested it on my ‚Äúquote‚Äù paragraphs and got a really nice effect:

My thinking process went like this:

  1. Style the border on the body.
  2. Write all the text, including that <hr>.
  3. Sort out body width, margins, padding.
  4. Group dates, article titles, quote blocks, and regular text as separate classes.
  5. Style each class.
  6. Style the <hr>.

Next session will focus on Bootstrap. I‚Äôve never used it before, so I‚Äôm really excited to see what that‚Äôs like! I heard it can make my coding experience a little easier and faster. üôÇ
